facts.text: The respondent Jagan Nath filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Punjab High Court which was allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Jagan Nath filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Punjab High Court which was allowed.

facts.text: The High Court ordered the Union of India and the appellant Sohan Lal to forthwith restore possession of house No. 35 situated in West Patel Nagar, Delhi to Jagan Nath.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court ordered the respondent The Union of India and the appellant Sohan Lal to forthwith restore possession of house No. 35 situated in West Patel Nagar, Delhi to Jagan Nath.

facts.text: The appellant applied for and obtained special leave to appeal to this Court against the High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order of the High Court the appellant applied for and obtained special leave to appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Jagan Nath is a displaced person and a refugee from Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath is a displaced person and a refugee from Pakistan.

facts.text: The Government of India devised schemes for rehabilitation of refugees including sale of houses constructed in West Patel Nagar.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India had devised various schemes for the rehabilitation of refugees. One of these was a scheme for sale of certain houses constructed by the Government of India for refugees in West Patel Nagar.

facts.text: Under the scheme, applications were not intended from displaced persons already allotted agricultural land in East Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: It was not intended under the scheme to entertain applications from displaced persons who had already been allotted agricultural land in East Punjab.

facts.text: Eligibility for allotment: displaced persons registered before August 15, 1948 and gainfully employed.

anchor.surface_text: According to the procedure prescribed in order to give effect to the scheme, only those displaced persons, who were registered before the 15th of August, 1948, and were gainfully employed, were eligible for allotment of a house.

facts.text: Jagan Nath registered as a refugee on December 31, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath had got himself registered as a refugee on December 31, 1947.

facts.text: Jagan Nath made application in the prescribed form.

anchor.surface_text: He had made his application in the prescribed form.

facts.text: Jagan Nath deposited Rs. 5,600 as sale price after prima facie eligibility accepted.

anchor.surface_text: He had deposited the sum of Rs. 5,600 as the sale price after his prima facie eligibility had been accepted.

facts.text: Jagan Nath deposited ground rent for the plot after being informed of allotment of a two-roomed enclosed verandah box-type house.

anchor.surface_text: He had also deposited the ground rent for the plot on which the house had been built, having been informed previously that it had been decided to allot him a two-roomed enclosed verandah box-type house in West Patel Nagar.

facts.text: Jagan Nath informed that allotment by drawing lots on February 15, 1952 at 3 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: He was informed that the allotment of a particular house would be decided by drawing lots at site on February 15, 1952, at 3 p.m.

facts.text: House No. 35 fell to Jagan Nath's lot in the drawing of lots.

anchor.surface_text: As the result of the drawing of lots, house No. 35, the property in dispute in this appeal, fell to his lot.

facts.text: On May 10, 1952, Accommodation Officer moved Jagan Nath's family into house No. 35.

anchor.surface_text: According to Jagan Nath, on May 10, 1952, the Accommodation Officer in his absence removed the members of his family along with his entire belongings to the house in dispute in a truck and he and his family thus entered into possession of the house in dispute.

facts.text: Jagan Nath evicted from house on September 27, 1952 by warrant dated September 11, 1952 under s. 25 of Ordinance III of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath, however, was evicted from the house in dispute on September 27, 1952, by virtue of a warrant of eviction dated September 11, 1952, purporting to have been issued under s. 25 of Ordinance III of 1952.

facts.text: Possession of house given to appellant on October 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: After his eviction, possession of the house in dispute was given to the appellant on October 3, 1952.

facts.text: Appellant is a displaced person.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, who is also a displaced person,

facts.text: Appellant applied for allotment on February 27, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: had applied on February 27, 1952, for allotment of a house in West Patel Nagar.

facts.text: Appellant deposited Rs. 5,600 as sale price and complied with conditions.

anchor.surface_text: He had made the deposit of Rs. 5,600 as sale price and had apparently complied with all the necessary conditions for allotment of a house to him

facts.text: House No. 35 allotted to appellant on July 31, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and the house in dispute was allotted to him on July 31, 1952.

facts.text: Appellant in possession of house since October 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has been in possession of the disputed house since October 3, 1952.

facts.text: There was a serious dispute on questions of fact between the parties and whether Jagan Nath had acquired title.

anchor.surface_text: There was a serious dispute on questions of fact between the parties and also whether Jagan Nath had acquired in law any title to the property in dispute.

facts.text: No letter of allotment issued to Jagan Nath.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath had entered into a transaction with the Union of India up to a certain stage with respect to the property in dispute, but no letter of allotment had been issued him.

facts.text: Jagan Nath informed that property could not be allotted as he was allotted land in East Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, he had been informed, when certain facts became known, that the property in question could not be allotted to him as he was a displaced person who had been allotted land in East Punjab.

facts.text: Union of India discovered Jagan Nath allotted agricultural land in District of Hissar prior to application, hence ineligible.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the Union of India is that under the scheme Jagan Nath was not eligible for allotment of a house in West Patel Nagar, as it was subsequently discovered that he had been allotted, previous to his application, agricultural land in the District of Hissar.

facts.text: Letter of allotment issued to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had complied with all the conditions imposed by the Union of India and a letter of allotment was actually issued to him

facts.text: Eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of s. 3 of Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950 and illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act. His eviction, therefore, was illegal.

facts.text: No evidence or finding that appellant in collusion with Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence and no finding of the High Court that the appellant was in collusion with the Union of India or that he had knowledge that the eviction of Jagan Nath was illegal.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and set aside the High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court erred in allowing the application of Jagan Nath filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution and making the order it did. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.

issues.text: whether in proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution such a declaration ought to be made and restoration of the property to Jagan Nath be ordered

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances to be mentioned hereafter, it is a matter for serious consideration whether in proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution such a declaration ought to be made and restoration of the property to Jagan Nath be ordered. Jagan Nath had entered into a transaction with the Union of India up to a certain stage with respect to the property in dispute, but no letter

issues.text: what rights were acquired by the former in the property up to the stage when the latter informed Jagan Nath that the property would not be allotted to him

anchor.surface_text: As between Jagan Nath and the Union of India it will be necessary to decide what rights were acquired by the former in the property up to the stage when the latter informed Jagan Nath that the property would not be allotted to him. Another question for decision will be whether Jagan Nath was allowed to enter into possession of the property because it was allotted to him or under a misapprehension as the Union of India was misled by the contents of his application.

issues.text: whether Jagan Nath was allowed to enter into possession of the property because it was allotted to him or under a misapprehension as the Union of India was misled by the contents of his application

issues.text: Did the appellant thereby acquire a legal right to hold the property as against Jagan Nath

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was accordingly given possession of the property after Jagan Naths eviction. The appellant had complied with all the conditions imposed by the Union of India and a letter of allotment was actually issued to him and he entered into possession of the property in dispute under the authority of the Union of India. Did the appellant thereby acquire a legal right to hold the property as against Jagan Nath ?

arguments.claim: Writ under Art.226 inappropriate for declaration of title and restoration when facts and law disputed

anchor.surface_text: We do not propose to enquire into the merits of the rival claims of title to the property in dispute set up by the appellant and Jagan Nath. If we were to do so, we would be entering into a field of investigation which is more appropriate for a Civil Court

arguments.claim: Eviction of Jagan Nath illegal contravening s.3 Public Premises Eviction Act

anchor.surface_text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act. His eviction, therefore, was illegal.

arguments.claim: Mandamus does not issue against private individual unless public duty or collusion proved

anchor.surface_text: Normally, a writ of mandamus does not issue to or an order in the nature of mandamus is not made against a private individual. Such an order is made against a person directing him to do some particular thing, specified in the order, which appertains to his office and is in the nature of a public duty Halsburys Laws of England Vol. 11, Lord Simonds Edition, p. 84

arguments.claim: No mandamus to oust de facto possessor without proving colourable transaction; analogous to quo warranto for office title

anchor.surface_text: where a person has been de facto elected to a corporate office, and has accepted and acted in the office, the validity of the election and the title to the office can only be tried by proceeding on a quo warranto information. A mandamus will not lie unless the election can be shown to be merely colourable.

arguments.claim: High Court erred in allowing Art.226 petition and ordering restoration

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court erred in allowing the application of Jagan Nath filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution and making the order it did. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.

holdings.text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act. His eviction, therefore, was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act. His eviction, therefore, was illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No prior notice served as mandatorily required by s.3 of Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950 before carrying out eviction.

holdings.text: There is no evidence and no finding of the High Court that the appellant was in collusion with the Union of India or that he had knowledge that the eviction of Jagan Nath was illegal.

anchor.surface_text: There is no evidence and no finding of the High Court that the appellant was in collusion with the Union of India or that he had knowledge that the eviction of Jagan Nath was illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of record reveals absence of evidence or High Court finding on collusion or knowledge of illegality.

holdings.text: Normally, a writ of mandamus does not issue to or an order in the nature of mandamus is not made against a private individual. Such an order is made against a person directing him to do some particular thing, specified in the order, which appertains to his office and is in the nature of a public duty.

anchor.surface_text: Normally, a writ of mandamus does not issue to or an order in the nature of mandamus is not made against a private individual. Such an order is made against a person directing him to do some particular thing, specified in the order, which appertains to his office and is in the nature of a public duty Halsburys Laws of England Vol. 11, Lord Simonds Edition, p. 84 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandamus enforces public duties pertaining to office; cites Halsbury's Laws of England.

holdings.text: He was entitled to be evicted in due course of law and a writ of mandamus could issue to or an order in the nature of mandamus could be made against the Union of India to restore possession of the property to Jagan Nath from which he had been evicted the property was still in the possession of the Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: He was entitled to be evicted in due course of law and a writ of mandamus could issue to or an order in the nature of mandamus could be made against the Union of India to restore possession of the property to Jagan Nath from which he had been evicted the property was still in the possession of the Union of India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illegal eviction by public authority permits mandamus against it for restoration if property remains in its possession.

holdings.text: We cannot see why in principle there should be a distinction made between such a case and the case of a person, who has, apparently, entered into bona fide possession of a property without knowledge that any person had been illegally evicted therefrom.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot see why in principle there should be a distinction made between such a case and the case of a person, who has, apparently, entered into bona fide possession of a property without knowledge that any person had been illegally evicted therefrom.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogous to quo warranto for de facto office holders; mandamus does not lie against bona fide de facto possessor unless colourable transaction.

holdings.text: In our opinion, all these questions should be decided in a properly constituted suit in a Civil Court rather than in proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, all these questions should be decided in a properly constituted suit in a Civil Court rather than in proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Disputed questions of fact and law on title and rights require trial in civil court, not writ proceedings.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the High Court erred in allowing the application of Jagan Nath filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution and making the order it did. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court erred in allowing the application of Jagan Nath filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution and making the order it did. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Writ jurisdiction under Art.226 inappropriate for disputed facts/title, mandamus unavailable against private party sans collusion, alternative civil remedy exists.

anchor.surface_text: R. v. Chester Corporation 1855 25 L.J.Q.B. 61 Regina v. Chester, Mayor, etc.

precedents.cited_proposition: it is an inflexible rule of law that where a person has been de facto elected to a corporate office, and has accepted and acted in the office, the validity of the election and the title to the office can only be tried by proceeding on a quo warranto information. A mandamus will not lie unless the election can be shown to be merely colourable
precedents.cited_holding: A mandamus will not lie unless the election can be shown to be merely colourable

anchor.surface_text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act. His eviction, therefore, was illegal.

In our opinion, the High Court erred in allowing the application of Jagan Nath filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution and making the order it did. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is

Normally, a writ of mandamus does not issue to or an order in the nature of mandamus is not made against a private individual. Such an order is made against a person directing him to do some particular thing, specified in the order, which appertains to his office and is in the nature of a public duty Halsburys Laws of England Vol. 11, Lord Simonds Edition, p. 84 .
